text:

text:
\0(%촀\02\0Ѐ촃Sea grapes\0￿ are a marine algae that

label: DiveFish_02831
text:
Ah, the \02\0Ā촃sea urchin\0￿n\0\0(촀\0the unabashed

(%촀\0Its venomous spines are an effective

label: DiveFish_02832
text:
('촀\0Do not mistake the \02\0Ȁ촃acorn barnacle\0￿

\0lobsters\0￿, you see. 

resemblance is hard to spot.

\0 what with being
attached to rocks and such.
(1촀\0But truth be told, 
\0baby barnacles are

\0 drifting shell-less
about the sea before settling down.
()촀\0Once they find a good rock to affix

\0they float free no

("촀\0Do adult \02\0Ȁ촃acorn barnacles\0￿ ever look

label: DiveFish_02833
text:
\0(촀\02\0Ȁ촃Oysters \0￿are marvelous mollusks

()촀\0That is,
\0 these bivalves tend to live

(촀\0These reef-like structures provide

label: DiveFish_02834
text:
("촀\0The \02\0Ā촃turban shell\0￿ is a sea snail

\0(6촀\0er, 

round,

(촀\0Why,
\0 it is a trapdoor of sorts!\0\0()촀\0When danger approaches,

\0((!촀\0And bravo, I say! 

label: DiveFish_02835
text:
(촀\0My feathers, but the \02\0Ȁ촃abalone\0￿ is a

the outside, 
\0(촀\0one would think it

("촀\0But take a gander inside, and you'll

\0(1촀\0the \02\0Ȁ촃abalone\0￿'s home is a
shimmering beauty to behold!
(촀\0The inner layer of the shell is made

label: DiveFish_02838
text:
(&촀\0Did you know the famed \02\0Ā촃pearl oyster

\0 hootie-hoo!

label: DiveFish_02839
text:
\0(촀\0\0￿Ah, the \02\0Ā촃scallop\0￿! 

(%촀\0Medusa herself would be most

text:

\0ehn\0\0
\0
grab hold of dinner guests as well.

text:
The \02\0Ā촃sea cucumber\0￿, 

Brace yourself, I sayn\0\0

(촀\0Hoo hoo,

(촀\0or perform beneath a big top.

label: DiveFish_02844
text:
(촀\0Marine \02\0Ā촃flatworms \0￿aren\0\0welln\0\0

\0flatworms\0￿ can clone themselves

label: DiveFish_02845
text:
(촀\0Think carefully before you mock the
\02\0Ā촃mantis shrimp\0￿ for its diminutive size.

I warn you,

Not only are its forelimbs shaped

text:
()촀\0The \02\0Ā촃sweet shrimp \0￿spends the first

label: DiveFish_02847
text:
(촀\0The \02\0Ā촃tiger prawn \0￿is a hearty

label: DiveFish_02848
text:
("촀\0It is the \02\0Ā촃spiny lobster\0￿'s\0 \0￿lengthy

having found a way to use those

label: DiveFish_02849
text:
(%촀\0The \02\0Ā촃lobster \0￿is rather famous for its

label: DiveFish_02850
text:
(%촀\0The \02\0Ā촃snow crab\0￿ truly lives up to its

label: DiveFish_02852
text:
(5촀\0The \02\0Ā촃red king crab\0￿ is a mighty

thought to be descended from
\0hermit crabs\0￿, you see.

\0(촀\0 GASP!
\0(

label: DiveFish_02853
text:
(촀\0Hoooot

\0 I do so hope to not
hyperventilate as I regale you with
the \02\0Ā촃spider crab\0￿'s qualities.

on earthn\0\0

from claw to claw and weigh up to 40

text:
(촀\0With its eight limbs, three hearts,

\02\0Ȁ촃octopus\0￿ is quite the wonder!

text:

eel-shaped fish that loves to burrow
in the sandy ocean floor.
(촀\0These silly things are known for
popping their heads out of the sand
to nibble on plankton drifting by.
()촀\0Some say this makes them look like
plants sprouting in a gardenn\0\0hence
the name \02\0Ā촃spotted garden eel\0￿.
(촀\0But I think they look more like
prairie dogs peeking out of desert
hidey-holes.
"Prairie eels" has a lovely ring,
\0(&촀\0
don't you think?

label: DiveFish_02856
text:
(촀\0The \02\0Ā촃chambered nautilus \0￿is perhaps
best known for its gorgeous shell.\0\0(촀\0Not only does this shell's interior
shine with a pearly luster,
\0 it features
a near-perfect natural spiral.
('촀\0But those aren't the \0chambered
nautilus\0￿'s only bragging rights.\0\0(촀\0This cephalopod can have up to
90 tentacles, it's said!\0\0()촀\0These arms come coated with a
sticky substance that helps the
nautilus capture its preyn\0\0
(9촀\0Which is far better than using
them for overly long hugs, I say.

label: DiveFish_02857
text:
("촀\0Some might say it's good luck to
catch a \02\0Ā촃horseshoe crab\0￿.
\0( (	촀\0But I am
NOT among them, eh wot!
Though called a "crab,"
\0 (+촀\0this beast is
an arthropod and thus more akin
to spiders and scorpions!
(촀\0Its long tail resembles a scorpion
stinger, in fact!
\0(\0K (촀\0Though it's quite harmless,
they say.
()촀\0\0dA "living fossil," 
\0the \0horseshoe
crab\0￿ has been around since before
the dinosaurs.
(촀\0\0KWith that tank-like shell, I suppose it WOULD
be the one to survive.\0\0(9촀\0\0dBut here's what truly rattles me to
my beakn\0\0\0\0(촀\0During breeding season, 
\0\0horseshoe
crabs\0￿ crawl up on the beach and
make nests together in the hundreds.


\0(촀\0HUNDREDS OF \0HORSESHOE CRABS\0￿!
\0(
	\0\0\0(+촀\0\0KAnd with that I can say no more.\0d

label: DiveFish_02858
text:
("촀\0Growing up to nearly 20 inches,
\0(촀\0 the
sea-dwelling \02\0Ā촃giant isopod\0￿ is the
world's largest cousin of the \0pill bug\0￿.
(+촀\0\0KTwenty inches?!
\0 Twenty times as revolting, I say!\0\0(촀\0\0dMaking matters worse for those of us
who find the \0pill bug\0￿ repulsive
rather than "cute"n\0\0
(9촀\0The \02\0Ā촃giant isopod\0￿ can swim
shockingly fast and is known for
its voracious appetite.
(촀\0In fact, it's most happy when dining
on the carcasses of animals that
have sunk to the bottom of the sea!
This behavior has earned it a
nicknamen\0\0
\0(촀\0"the vacuum cleaner
of the deep."\0K
(촀\0Why must nature play such awful pranks on me?\0d

label: DiveFish_06920
text:
\0(촀\0\0￿The \02\0Ā촃firefly squid\0￿ is a wee migratory
squid that barely reaches three
inches in length.
(%촀\0And though they usually live in deep
water,
\0 they do venture to the coast
to spawn.
()촀\0Like their firefly namesakes, these
sparkling squid emit a blue
bioluminescent glow.
(1촀\0This glow may be used to threaten
enemies, 
\0communicate with friends,
or,
\0 perhaps,
\0 to lure food in.
(:촀\0Truth be told,
\0 we do not know for
sure why the \02\0Ā촃firefly squid\0￿ glows.
\0(6촀\0
We remain in the dark, as they say.

label: DiveFish_07191
text:
("촀\0The \02\0Ā촃gazami crab\0￿
\0 may be better
known by its more descriptive
namen\0\0
\0(%촀\0the Japanese blue crab.
(촀\0It gets its name from the blue tint
sometimes found on its shell
and legs.\0\0()촀\0Its paddle-like rear legs are what
help it to swim freely and
quickly through the water.
Of course,
\0(6촀\0 this \02\0Ā촃gazami crab \0￿couldn't
swim quickly enough to get away
from you!

label: DiveFish_07203
text:
(촀\0Beware the \02\0Ā촃vampire squid\0￿, I say!
\0
This eight-armed deep-sea monster
is out to drink your blood!
(촀\0Hoo hoo, 
\0ha ha!
\0 I only jest!\0\0(9촀\0Ahem!
\0( ()촀\0The \02\0Ā촃vampire squid\0￿ does, in
fact, live deep in the ocean where
almost no light pervades.
(:촀\0But while it looks like it could nibble
on your neckn\0\0
\0(6촀\0it nibbles on bits of
dead plankton and algae instead.
(촀\0By all accounts,
\0 the \02\0Ā촃vampire squid
\0￿is a gentle sort who squirts
bioluminescent goo at foes.
So,(&촀\0 how did it get the eerie official
name "Vampyroteuthis infernalis"?
\0(
(9촀\0\0KThat means “vampire squid from heck," you see.\0d
(촀\0The problem is the squid's "cloak."
\0(
(촀\0Its arms are webbed with velvet-red
skin and lined with toothy spikes!
Plainly put, 
\0(촀\0this genial squid looks
for all the world like a vampire who
went for a swim.

label: DiveFish_07214
text:
(촀\0\0Gigas giant clams\0￿ live in warm-water
coral reefs and are the biggest
bivalves in the world.
()촀\0Growing as wide as six feet and
weighing up to 600 pounds, these
clams can live to be 100 years old.
(촀\0And yes, these mighty creatures
look as though they could eat a
swimmer whole.
(촀\0But they eat plankton instead and
get valuable nutrients from an algae
they live in symbiosis with.
(1촀\0Indeed, these enormous gents get
all the sustenance they need by lying
face up with their shells half-open.
If such was my life,
\0(6촀\0 I'd be happy as a
clam too.

label: DiveFish_07228
text:
(촀\0Try not to gawk as you look upon the
\02\0Ā촃sea pineapple\0￿. 
\0((촀\0Its peculiar look is
simply one of nature's many jokes.
Though it may look like a half-rotten
hunk of fruit, 
\0('촀\0the \02\0Ā촃sea pineapple\0￿ is
no plant, shellfish, or even \0sea slug\0￿.
()촀\0It's a tunicate, wot wotn\0\0a fancy
name for a shallow-water filter
feeder with a taste for plankton.
(촀\0It should be noted that the \0sea
pineapple\0￿ looks like a tadpole when
it's young and can still swim about.
(촀\0Alas,
\0 its youthful cuteness wears off
once it attaches itself for good to a
rock.
\0( ( 촀\0Ah,
\0 but let's put insults aside!
(촀\0\02\0Ā촃Sea pineapples\0￿ are full of water,
you see.
\0( (촀\0And I fear we're asking for
a squirt in the eye!

label: DiveFish_07245
text:
(1촀\0Ah, the \0(촀\0moon jellyfish\0￿n\0\0what's not to
love about this pretty floating flower
of the sean\0\0
(촀\0Well,
\0 I suppose its tentacles do give
a sting when touchedn\0\0
\0(촀\0but it's only
a mild thing to the likes of us.
('촀\0Other creatures may not be so fond
of this translucent beauty. 
\0((촀\0Though
who can blame them, really?
()촀\0\0Moon jellyfish\0￿ have stinging cells
called cnidocytes that kill fish and
other small critters that float by.
(%촀\0And they use their "oral arms" to pull
these morsels into their mouths and
stomachs.
Indeed, one need but observe the
\0moon jellyfish\0￿(촀\0 to see how brutal
AND beautiful nature can be.

label: DiveFish_07252
text:
(촀\0My feathers,
\0 could there be a more
adorable sea creature than the
\0(촀\0umbrella octopus\0￿?
\0((9촀\0 I daresay not!
(촀\0These deep-sea octopuses are on
the smallish side and use the cutest
ear-like fins to flutter about.
()촀\0Meanwhile, it's the web stretched
between their tentacles that gives
them their name.
(촀\0Hoo, it's true!
\0 With arms stretched
wide, they look for all the world
like an umbrella!
( 촀\0Though surely the last thing the
\0umbrella octopus\0￿ wantsn\0\0
\0(촀\0is to
stay dry.

label: DiveFish_07267
text:
(촀\0\0Slate pencil urchins\0￿ are a type of sea
urchin topped with thick, rounded
spines that resemble sticks of chalk.
()촀\0These urchins' spines protect
them not only from predators but
from violent waves as well.
()촀\0Found in coral reefs, they're usually
bright red, brown, or purple in color.\0\0(촀\0For all those bright colors, one would
think the \0slate pencil urchin \0￿to be
quite deadly.
(촀\0But all those pretty colors, it seems,
are just a pretty show.

label: DiveFish_07278
text:
("촀\0\0Whelks\0￿ are sea snails that migrate
from deep water to shallow water
when the weather changes.
()촀\0Avid carnivores, they feed on worms,
crustaceans, and mollusks.\0\0In fact, these wily snails have been
known to use their own shells ( 촀\0to pry
open the shells of their victims!
()촀\0They then use a rough tongue-like
organ with thousands of tiny teeth
to lick their victims' shells clean.
(7촀\0Ehn\0\0you might want to put that
image out of your mind when it's
your turn to dine.

label: DiveFish_07303
text:
(7촀\0Never have I seen a creature that
walks the line between creepy and
cute quite like the \0sea pig\0￿ does.
()촀\0\0Sea pigs\0￿ are, in fact, a type of \0sea
cucumber\0￿ that lives deep down on
the ocean floor.
About four inches long, 
\0("촀\0these soft
pinkish oddities use tube-like
legs and feelers to get around.
()촀\0Thus they snuffle through the mud,
\0
slurping up particles from decaying
carcasses.
Meanwhile, predators be warnedn\0\0
(9촀\0This little piggy tastes like poison.

label: DiveFish_07308
text:
(촀\0The \02\0Ā촃Dungeness crab\0￿ wears a pretty
fan-shaped shell that's often done
up in purple hues.
But eye-catching colors aside,
\0 ( 촀\0this
fellow can be surprisingly hard
to spot!
(6촀\0That's because the \02\0Ā촃Dungeness crab\0￿
is something of an expert hider.\0\0(촀\0When scared, 
\0it plays a nifty trick!
\0
()촀\0That is, 
\0it buries itself beneath
the sand with impressive speed.
(9촀\0"Now you see me, now you don't,"
\0
it says (촀\0as it vanishes before your
very eyes!

label: DiveFish_07318
text:
(촀\0The \02\0Ā촃Venus' flower basket\0￿ looks like
an otherworldly creature one would
find on an alien planet.
(촀\0But it is instead a remarkable sea
sponge found in the deepest parts
of the ocean.
()촀\0Its body is composed of silica and
looks like a sculpture or,
\0 perhaps,
\0
a vase made of glassy mesh.
(1촀\0I daresay the \02\0Ā촃Venus' flower basket\0￿
is one of nature's most impressive
works of art.

label: DiveFish_07411
text:
(촀\0Did you know the \0mussel\0￿ has a
beard?!\0\0(9촀\0Hoo!
\0 It's true! 
\0((촀\0Well,
\0 partially true,
anyway.\0\0()촀\0\0Mussels\0￿ have a special gland that
secretes a thing called "byssus" or
"byssal thread."
("촀\0They use these tough beard-like
fibers to anchor themselves to rocks
and keep themselves in place.
(촀\0So, you see, the \0mussel\0￿'s beard
is functional rather than
merely stylish.
Then again, 
\0(6촀\0perhaps all beards
should be this way.
